Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies



This Executive Summary is to inform all interested persons, including employees that the CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc.  is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM) Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119 and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP) Title 40 CFR Part 68, to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals. In this way we promote overall plant, employee and public safety.



These programs help this facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, these programs help prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoid physical property damage. Our safety programs are applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use, storage, handling, or combination of these activities. This facility has one refrigeration system using Anhydrous Ammonia as the refrigerant. The amount of Anhydrous Ammonia contained in this system is above the EPA threshold reporting quantity required to comply with the RMP standards. 



The stationary source and regulated substances handled



The regulated substance at this plant is anhydrous ammonia. Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the plant freezer systems. The refrigeration system holds a quantity of 15,000 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia. 



The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario.



Worst-case Scenario: The event that was modeled was the complete evacuation the ammonia system, which can hold 15,000 pounds of ammonia. It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor over a 10 minute time span and are subjected to a wind speed of 1.5 m/s with a stabil

ity class of F. The distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario is 1.1 miles with 4,066 people located within the affected radius (based on US Census 2000 data).



Alternative Release Scenario: The lifting of a pressure relief valve. Relief valves allow the escape of ammonia at a flow rate of 100. lbs/min. Weather conditions are assumed to be average values of 3 m/s wind speed and stability class D. The distance to the toxic endpoint is .1 miles and extends beyond the facility boundary. Based on the US Census 2000 data, approximately 125 people live within the toxic endpoint radius.



The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps



CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc. believes that the best way to prevent an accidental release is by being proactive in its approach to safety. This facility maintains information about the proper use of its equipment and the possible hazards. By following set operating procedures and maintenance routines, the process equipment within the facility will be operated at optimum conditions. Additionally, the release prevention program is constantly being improved by sustained employee training and regular compliance audits. Compliance with all applicable state codes and regulations ensures the continued safe operations of the CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc. facility. Also, the accidental prevention program is conducted in accordance with Process Safety Management (PSM) rules and regulations.



Five-year accident history



In the last five years, the CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc.-Bonner Springs, KS facility has not experienced a significant accidental ammonia release.



The emergency response program



A well planned emergency response program can make a tremendous difference in the potential off-site impacts of an accidental release. Swift, efficient actions can minimize the damage to both human population and the natural surroundings. To this end, CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc. has instructed e

mployees on the proper actions to take in the event of an accidental release. CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc. maintains a well-trained emergency response team and has a written emergency response plan, which specifies the details of the actions that will be taken in the event of an accidental release.



Planned changes to improve safety



CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc. is incorporating and addressing any recommendations resulting from the Process Hazard Analysis, Offsite Consequences, and program audits. The flexibility of the program allows CSM Bakery Products NA, Inc. to respond effectively to prevent or minimize any potential exposure to employees, the surrounding public, and/or the environment to a release of anhydrous ammonia. Specific actions taken to improve safety are the implementation of the Program 3 Prevention Program described above, improved operator training, administrative controls, and computerized system controls.
